body:
### Feature already in Vim?

_No_

### Feature description

I use a piece of software called [Cursorless](https://github.com/cursorless-dev/cursorless) which enables efficient structural editing by defining a meta language for targeting elements which depends on always on text decorations. The decorations could be anything, but in practice they tend to be SVGs of different colors that are placed on top of characters to allow the user to reference a particular element with minimal work. Cursorless is most widely used by the voice coding community. See [this gif](https://github.com/cursorless-dev/cursorless/blob/1a0616521bbc6d264f22fdad41e9a7773f9b0bee/images/bringArgueAirAndEachAfterDrum.gif) for an example of what the text decorations look like.

It would be great if neovim GUIs could support this type of text decoration, but I imagine it will require some server side changes.

Cross linking some related issues for posterity:
- https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/1767
- https://github.com/neovide/neovide/issues/1144
- https://github.com/neovide/neovide/issues/669
- https://github.com/neovide/neovide/issues/850

I'd also like to see this. Neovim users seem like the perfect audience for Cursorless given how it allows you to manipulate text. 

On top of that using Cursorless with Talon Voice can reduce the number of hotkeys you need to remember - or just give you more convenient ways to navigate nvim.
Related: @saidelike is working on some sort of Nvim + cursorless integration :) https://github.com/cursorless-dev/cursorless/pull/2256

> Related: @saidelike is working on some sort of Nvim + cursorless integration :) [cursorless-dev/cursorless#2256](https://github.com/cursorless-dev/cursorless/pull/2256)

This is only possible thanks to your great node-client work @justinmk ^_^

To be clear, I already have cursorless working in neovim but without text decorations (which is what the current issue is for). 

So I am able to reference things like lines by number, words by ordinal on the line. But I can't reference words directly as easily as if we had text decorations.

Obviously if there was progress in the current issue, that would help a lot integrating the full power of cursorless.
@saidelike do you plan on taking ownership of this issue next or is it beyond what you plan to do on the topic?

> @saidelike do you plan on taking ownership of this issue next or is it beyond what you plan to do on the topic?

I unfortunately won't have time/knowledge to lead work on text decorations, but if someone else does, I am happy to test it and provide feedbacks.

I think cursorless support can be achieved using [unicode overscripts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unicode_subscripts_and_superscripts) and background color on virtual text. 

Here is an example with quick command
```
:call nvim_buf_set_extmark(0, nvim_create_namespace("test"), 0, 7, {'id':1, 'virt_text': [["o\u0363", 'IncSearch']], 'virt_text_pos':'overlay'})
```
That produces:
![Screenshot from 2024-04-13 21-47-02](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/10254532/17e02032-cd8d-4856-a91f-4740add22a91)

The only problem I see is that this limits you to a font with support for that character set, I'm using Julia Mono. Maybe a font patcher could be created that creates the current cursorless shapes.
Someone in the talon slack suggested we may be able to use [kui.nvim](https://github.com/romgrk/kui.nvim) to make cursorless decorations. I thought it should be mentioned here as well.

> Someone in the talon slack suggested we may be able to use [kui.nvim](https://github.com/romgrk/kui.nvim) to make cursorless decorations. I thought it should be mentioned here as well.

It is the first time i hear about kitty but it currently only supports Linux or OS X iiuc? So no Windows support? See https://github.com/kovidgoyal/kitty/issues/640

@saidelike We discussed this before actually. It was me that suggested kui.nvim as a possibility. 

The important distinction here is that kui.nvim uses the kitty graphics protocol (KGP). It doesn't actually rely on the kitty terminal (just happens the protocol was created by the kitty terminal author). As far as I know any terminal that supports KGP should be usable with kui.nvim. Another popular terminal is wezterm which works on Linux, macOS, and Windows, and also supports KGP. It should work with kui.nvim afaik.

Another terminal graphics protocol that I think may eventually be more widely supported is sixel, which wezterm also supports, but the caveat is that there isn't an existing plugin like kui.nvim for sixel atm.

WRT to using unicode and background colors, this is something I'd considered in the past, but I actually think it isn't ideal. There are a couple of reasons:

1) I think a lot of people (including @saidelike ) will use cursorless+vscode for coding and cursorless+neovim only for terminal. The inconsistency between hats would be a significant cognitive overload imo.

2) It is common for syntax highlighting in terminal output, which would be ruined by using background coloring imo. For instance if you use bat to cat a script file with syntax highlighting, you'd end up with an unreadable rainbow of syntax highlight colors and cursorless hat background colors. As a full time developer using cursorless for over a year I can say the various different colored hats above the text only is already enough of a mental overhead as is, let alone changing the actual color of the text glyph/background itself. Honestly even without syntax highlighting the resulting rainbow might make most things unreadable.

The only way I could see it being usable with unicode only and colors is if there is a way to only color the accents glyph over the character, but afaik this is not possible.

> The only way I could see it being usable with unicode only and colors is if there is a way to only color the accents glyph over the character, but afaik this is not possible.

I was investigating a little bit more into the matter, apparently Unicode has  a very large ["Private user area" ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Private_Use_Areas) that is large enough to accommodate all the combinations of overscripts and colors. For example I was able to use the [nanoemoji](https://github.com/googlefonts/nanoemoji) to generate a colored font with ~1000 pokemon svg and use it the terminal :D
![Screenshot from 2024-04-21 10-01-48](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/10254532/ce8f7535-1879-4e36-82ef-6259a03d59d8)

I think accents are just a matter of setting a negative space before the glyph, but there space for all the letters/common symbols + hats in the PUAs if needed.

>  It is common for syntax highlighting in terminal output, which would be ruined by using background coloring imo. For instance if you use bat to cat a script file with syntax highlighting.

Ignoring the consistency aspect for a moment: for me the ideal would be using the existing colors of the semantic highlight + rainbow brackets to differentiate the elements instead of adding colors to the hat itself, something like [semshi](https://github.com/numirias/semshi) is very readable if you are used to it. Of course it is not for all people.

I don't think that's actually very practical, though it seems like a nice idea on the surface (I also like this type of semantic coloring and rainbow brackets). Let's just use the example of class member variables being colored green like in the first semshi screenshot. All of the variables will be green, and say you are limited to 8 hat shapes (realistically a lot of people use less iirc), if you don't independently color the hat, that gives you only 8 target variables on screen that can use the semantic coloring. Even in their tiny example there are already 8 variables references, so add one more to the code and what should the hat be? I generally have way more code on screen than in their example, and commonly in two splits. Maybe I'm missing something about how else you are envisioning it though.

I generally have way more code on screen than in their example, and commonly in two splits. Maybe I'm missing something about how else you are envisioning it though.

The idea is a little bit different, Let me elaborate:
First lest draw a distinction, semantic highlight and syntactic highlight are used interchangeably, but in this case we need to draw the distinction:
1. Syntactic Highlight: same elements in the grammar have the same color [semshi](https://github.com/numirias/semshi)
2. Semantic Highlight: same names in the namespace have the same color [semantic-highligh](https://github.com/jaxbot/semantic-highlight.vim)
3. Tree level Highlight: same depth level in the of symbols of the same type have the same color [nvim-ts-raimbow](https://github.com/HiPhish/nvim-ts-rainbow2)

I don't have an example of 1 and 2 working together in neovim as they conflict but there is an example from intellij that has features 1 and 2 and a [plugin for 3](https://plugins.jetbrains.com/plugin/10080-rainbow-brackets):
![image](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/10254532/c00d1a45-508e-4cac-8add-044ecb9ad727)

With these 3 combined I think that there is sufficient colors in the screen to not run into conflicts most of the time. I think a fallback option is still needed. The main limitation is when the same variable is used several times in the same context and the variable names has few letters, for instance let's make an old stile for loop:
```c
for (int id=0; id<3; id++) {
    arr1[id] += 1;
    arr2[id] = arr1[id] + 2;
   //..
}
```
In this example the variable "id" only has 2 letters so if you have 6 hats that leaves a maximum of 6*2=12 references in the screen at maximum, assuming the letters "i" and "d" are not occupied by other elements.

That's what I've said to me is the ideal situation, because the random color information of the hat would be greatly reduced being most hats a plain color, while maximizing the useful information of 1, 2, 3. But I understand the complexity of having it working properly for maybe not so much gain.
Should the above discussion move to https://github.com/neovim/neovim/discussions , or what are the (concise) takeaways for this issue?

From my perspective, it seems like we want/need:
- The ability to add SVG decorations to characters using one (or more) of: kitty graphics protocol, sixel, or unicode PUA
- Decorations should be color-able in order to be fully leveraged by existing tools like cursorless
- Decorations should be applicable to all common modes (like INSERT, NORMAL, VISUAL), including TERMINAL mode
- Done in a way that it is not limited to one specific neovim GUI implementation (like neovide, etc), but ideally neovim running in any console/gui supporting the chosen protocol(s)
